title: Emergency Provisions in the Indian Constitution

information.title: Types of Emergencies
information.description: The Indian Constitution provides for three types of emergencies: National Emergency (Article 352), State Emergency (Article 356), and Financial Emergency (Article 360).

information.title: National Emergency
information.description: The President can declare a National Emergency if India's security is threatened by war, external aggression, or armed rebellion. It affects fundamental rights and alters the federal structure of government.

information.title: State Emergency
information.description: Also known as President's Rule, it can be imposed if a state government cannot function according to constitutional provisions. The President takes over the state's administration through the Governor.

information.title: Financial Emergency
information.description: The President can declare a Financial Emergency if the financial stability or credit of India or any part of its territory is threatened. It has never been invoked so far.

information.title: Duration and Extension
information.description: Emergency proclamations must be approved by Parliament within one month. They can be extended for six months at a time by parliamentary approval.

information.title: Effects of Emergency
information.description: During a National Emergency, Fundamental Rights (except Articles 20 and 21) can be suspended. The federal structure becomes unitary, and Parliament can make laws on state subjects.
